standfirst: Bashar al-Assad attends his inauguration ceremony in Damascus where he is sworn in for a third term as president of Syria. Elections took place in the country in June, with many dismissing the result as a sham. Assad takes the oath of office with a hand on the Qur'an, signaling the start of another seven-year term
headline: Syria: Bashar al-Assad sworn in as president - video

standfirst: Almost 150,000 people were evacuated from their homes in the Philippines on Wednesday after typhoon Rammasun swept through Manila. Rammasun is the strongest storm to hit the country this year, cutting a path across the main island of Luzon before passing south of the capital on Wednesday, toppling trees and power lines and causing widespread blackouts
headline: Typhoon Rammasun: Philippines suffers widespread destruction – video report

standfirst: The treasurer has denied that Clive Palmer is his 'daddy' despite claims from Nine Network TV host Karl Stefanovic that this is why the government is struggling to pass some of its legislation. Hockey said that the Australian public was his 'daddy and mummy', shifting the blame for not passing legislation onto the Greens
headline: Clive Palmer not my daddy, Joe Hockey insists – video

standfirst: At least 27 people killed in series of bombings, including three in space of 10 minutes, shaking city's fragile sense of security
headline: Baghdad bombings kill dozens

standfirst: The aftermath of five bomb explosions in Baghdad on Saturday, which left up to 26 people dead in a mostly Shia neighbourhood. The series of bombings, including three in the space of less than 10 minutes, shook the fragile sense of security the capital. The attacks are among the most significant in Baghdad since insurgents led by the Islamic State (Isis) captured Iraq's second-largest city of Mosul last month
headline: Baghdad bombings aftermath - video

standfirst: Aftermath of a car bomb that exploded in a crowded market in Afghanistan's eastern province of Paktika, killing at least 89 people on Tuesday. There appears to be no government or military target among the dead, apart from the two policemen who tried to stop the bomber. The deadliest previous suicide attack was in southern Kandahar province in 2008, when at least 80 people were killed
headline: Afghanistan car bomb blast aftermath - video

standfirst: Typhoon Rammasun, which caused at least 64 deaths in the Philippines, makes landfall in Wenchang City on south China's island province of Hainan. The storm, which was downgraded as it passed over the Philippines, gained strength again over the South China Sea and is now causing extensive damage in Hainan. When the storm reaches mainland China, it is expected to produce strong gales of up to 93mph, heavy rain and tidal surges
headline: Typhoon Rammasun makes landfall in China - video

standfirst: Supporters on both sides of tightly contested race have taken a proactive role in election monitoring

standfirst: Shadow assistant treasurer Andrew Leigh reckons Joe Hockey's plan to shed tax office jobs is a dud, given ATO data which suggest they make more in revenue than their sackings will save. Join him in front of the Guardian Australia whiteboard for a show and tell – it's 'Smokin' Joe' in the firing line as Leigh makes the case for the number-crunching civil servants

standfirst:
He doesn’t drink, he’s reading Dostoevsky and, no, he doesn’t wear a disguise. A year after blowing the whistle on the NSA, America’s most wanted talks frankly about his life as a hero-pariah – and why the world remains ‘more dangerous than Orwell imagined’.

• Read a transcript of the interview
headline: I, spy: Edward Snowden in exile

standfirst: It's a big hit in Central America with its lyrics about la bestia, or the 'train of death', that migrants ride up to the US border. But few listeners know that it is all part of a multi-million dollar propaganda campaign to dissuade them
headline: La Bestia: the hit song the US border agency made to scare off immigrants

standfirst: Forty years ago, a vast molten cavity known as the Darvaza crater – nicknamed the "door to hell" – opened up in the desert of north Turkmenistan, and has been burning ever since. Now, Canadian explorer George Kourounis has become the first to make the descent into the fiery pit to look for signs of life

standfirst: A German reporter sings Chancellor Angela Merkel happy birthday at a news conference in Brussels on Thursday. The journalist embarked on the serenade presumably with the expectation that he would be singing in chorus with his colleagues. But no other journalists joined in, prompting Merkel to remark that she should have sung along. Merkel turned 60 on Thursday
headline: Angela Merkel's Happy Birthday fail - video

standfirst: Inland from the glamorous beaches, the Italian island boasts fine food and culture –  if only they could market it
headline: A few miles from the caviar coast, the 'real' Sardinia sings a sad song of lost opportunity

standfirst: The prime minister says that the parliament has listened to the Australian people and ditched the 'useless, obstructive' carbon tax. The tax, which 'didn't even help the environment' has been removed, he said. Abbott added that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will be on hand to make sure cost savings are returned to the public
headline: Useless, obstructive carbon tax is gone, says Tony Abbott – video

standfirst: Hernán Alonso Villa, aka The Mouse, is linked to 400 murders and faces smuggling, extortion and people trafficking charges
headline: Colombian drug lord El Ratón arrested in Spain

standfirst: Merkel celebrates her 60th birthday after eight and a half years as German chancellor. Share your thoughts on her time in power
headline: Angela Merkel turns 60: what has her leadership meant to you?

standfirst: The Australian Greens leader, Christine Milne, says it is the height of hypocrisy for the treasurer, Joe Hockey, to talk about a budget emergency on the day that $18bn in revenue is going back to 'the big miners and the big polluters' through the repeal of the carbon tax. The government is 'all about rewarding the big end of town', Milne says
headline: Carbon tax repeal means budget emergency claims ludicrous, Christine Milne says – video

standfirst: GOP candidate Scott Brown has been labeled 'anti-women' by his Democratic rival, a label particularly toxic in New Hampshire

standfirst:
Edward Snowden, the NSA whistleblower, talks exclusively to Alan Rusbridger, editor-in-chief of the Guardian, and reporter Ewen MacAskill in Moscow. The 31-year-old former intelligence analyst discusses whether he is a Russian spy, his likely fate if he returns to the US and the relevance of George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four in the age of Google

• Read more here and the full interview on Friday
headline: Edward Snowden: 'If I end up in chains in Guantánamo I can live with that' - video interview

standfirst: Incoming Liberal-National party senator for Queensland James McGrath has called for the abolition of the health and education departments and the sale of the ABC if perceived left-wing bias is not addressed. standfirst: Traffic on Melbourne's Monash Freeway was delayed on Thursday morning after a truck lost its load of apples, leaving a trail of the fruit down the highway. standfirst: Nine people have been killed and at least 43 others injured after a bus crashed on a German motorway near the city of Dresden. The crash, which occurred on Saturday morning, involved a Polish coach, a minibus and a Ukrainian coach, according to police, seven of those killed were travelling in the minibus

standfirst: As the death toll in Gaza passes 500, UN chief Ban Ki-moon calls on Israel to 'exercise maximum restraint' and spare civilian lives. Israeli continues to shell Gaza from the air and the ground on Monday. Sunday was one of the bloodiest days in Gaza, with Israel targeting the eastern neighbourhood of Shujai'iya
headline: Gaza death toll soars as UN urges Israel restraint – video

standfirst: As in the field, Israel deploys superior strength and resources as both sides attack each other on Twitter, Facebook and YouTube

standfirst: Israeli troops are seen positioned near the Gaza border on Wednesday morning, as Israel resumed its air strikes in Gaza a day after an Egyptian-proposed ceasefire deal, leaving at least three Palestinians dead. The Israeli military say that since the ceasefire deal was to have gone into effect, Hamas had fired 123 rockets at Israel, one killing a civilian - the first Israeli fatality in the fighting

standfirst: Hamas calls for international action over an Israeli air strike on Gaza beach that left four children dead and another seriously injured. Spokesman Sami Abu Zuhri calls on Ban Ki-moon and the United Nations to act on what he describes as Israeli war crimes. Gaza health officials say 207 Palestinians, most of them civilians, have died in the Israeli offensive since 8 July
headline: Gaza: Israeli strike kills four children on beach - video

standfirst: The aftermath of a helicopter crash in Gwangju, south-west South Korea, on Thursday, in which the entire crew of five firefighters died. The helicopter was reportedly returning to base after assisting in the search for missing passengers of the April ferry disaster. The deaths bring the total number of fatalities of those involved in the search to seven. Two divers previously drowned while searching inside the ship
headline: South Korean firefighters' helicopter ablaze after crash – video

standfirst: Footage showing Israeli soldiers mounting a ground invasion into the Gaza Strip overnight, after 10 days of aerial bombardment and rocket fire between the opposing parties. As Israeli troops prepared to move in, former US secretary of state Hillary Clinton told a US television journalist she would 'prefer' that Israel did not launch an invasion. For more go to live blog

standfirst: Palestinians march in a funeral procession on Saturday for three children from one family killed in an Israeli attack on Friday, as the Palestinian death toll tops 300. Josh Earnest claims Hamas should accept a ceasefire deal and stop firing rockets aimed at Israeli civilians. Gaza says 207 Palestinians have been killed in the violence which began on 8 July; one Israeli has been killed by rocket fire from Hamas

standfirst: There is a deafening explosion, then a second. Four children are dead. Four survivors reach the safety of our hotel

standfirst: Israeli army footage shows night incursions by ground troops into Gaza. The country's prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, announces a 'widening' of operations against Hamas on Friday. Israel has also stepped up its bombardment from air and sea, in what it describes as a response to mounting rocket attacks fired by Hamas into Israeli cities. A Gaza news agency premises was damaged by an Israeli airstrike

standfirst: Israel and Hamas exchange fire on the Israel-Gaza border on Thursday night as the Israeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu instructs the military to begin a ground offensive in Gaza. Israel's decision to move troops into Gaza follows clashes earlier in the day as a temporary humanitarian ceasefire ended
headline: Israel exchanges fire with Hamas as its troops begin a ground offensive in Gaza - video

standfirst: Israel wants to locate and destroy tunnels dug by Hamas and expand significantly the buffer zone along the border
headline: Israel targets 'terror tunnels' in Gaza ground invasion

standfirst: Border crossing is a lifeline for Palestinians, but Egypt does not want to gift Hamas something that would increase its popularity
headline: Reopening of Rafah crossing top priority for Hamas in ceasefire talks

standfirst: Contrast with Gaza destruction is striking but Tel Aviv is not always this peaceful, with rockets a continuing threat
headline: In bustling Tel Aviv, Israelis feel strain of war

standfirst: Information shows 189 of 298 people on board were Dutch, but overall reaction to tragedy in Netherlands is restrained
headline: Dutch king offers condolences to relatives of people on flight MH17

standfirst: Video taken on Friday purports to show the black box recorder of flight MH17 being removed from its crash site in Ukraine, as cranes were used to remove part of the plane over the weekend. Rebel fighters say they have the black box and are prepared to hand it to international experts when they arrive in the town of Donetsk
headline: MH17: purported black box recorder being removed from crash site – video

standfirst: Anger grows in EU and leaders prepare fresh sanctions against Moscow as separatists obstruct access to crash site
headline: Cameron tells Putin shooting down of MH17 was 'unacceptable'

standfirst: The prime minister fears Russia will allow continued interference at the site and of the 298 victims
headline: MH17: Tony Abbott says Russia cannot 'wash its hands' of airline tragedy

standfirst: The Security Service of Ukraine has released a recording of what it says are conversations involving a rebel fighter named 'Bes', Russian Colonel Vasyl Mykolaiovych Geranin and Cossack military leader Mykola Kozitsyn discussing the downing of a Malaysia Airlines jet over eastern Ukraine. The transcript with this video was obtained independently by the Guardian
headline: MH17: recording shows Russian colonel and rebels 'discussing disaster' – video

standfirst:
Session held ahead of Aids 2014 conference told email exchanges show about 100 attendees booked on flight MH17

Pim de Kuijer, my friend and Aids campaigner, killed in MH17 crash
headline: Aids conference says 100 researchers may have been on flight MH17

standfirst:
• 'It's a hell of a pinpoint operation' captured on open microphone
• Obama tells Netanyahu of 'serious concern' at rising casualties
• Israel kills scores in Gaza suburb in deadliest attack so far
• Opinion: how the occupation of Gaza corrupts the occupier
headline: Unguarded comments suggest Kerry frustration at civilian toll in Gaza

standfirst: Israeli prime minister set to authorise call-up of more reserve soldiers, as death toll from Israel's bombing passes 200 in Gaza
headline: Binyamin Netanyahu: Hamas has 'shut the door' to diplomatic solutions

standfirst: Thousands of protesters have taken to the streets of Sydney in opposition to the Israeli ground invasion of Gaza. The Australian government has refrained from directly criticising Israel, instead censuring Hamas for refusing to accept an Egyptian-brokered ceasefire proposal. Protesters decried Israel as a 'terrorist state' while a number shouted 'God is great' in Arabic
headline: Thousands protest in Sydney over Israel ground invasion of Gaza - video

standfirst: Hamas unable to persuade Israel and Egypt to release recently captured prisoners and to ease blockade
headline: Israel's attack on Gaza follows talks in which no one was ready to back down

standfirst: The US president says he has 'serious concerns' over the rising number of deaths on both sides of recent violence between Israel and Gaza. Barack Obama claims that while he supports Israel's right to defend itself against rockets fired by Hamas, he is hopeful the two sides can reach a ceasefire agreement. US Secretary of State John Kerry is on his way to the Middle East to facilitate talks between the two sides
headline: Barack Obama: we are focused on Israel-Gaza ceasefire - video

standfirst: Negotiations between Israel and Hamas reach 'critical 24 hours' after Cairo talks during brief humanitarian ceasefire
headline: Israel seeks ceasefire that will restore authority to Abbas, says official

standfirst: Our correspondent has watched as 12 days of terror have overwhelmed the region, leaving at least 300 dead
headline: As war returns to Gaza, it is the children who are frozen in fear

standfirst: Israeli prime minister fires deputy defence minister Danny Danon for saying Hamas humiliated Israel by setting peace conditions
headline: Netanyahu criticised by cabinet members over Gaza crisis

standfirst: Moscow faces bank curbs over new public-sector projects, and more asset-freezing for firms 'undermining Ukraine sovereignty'
headline: EU poised to cut funding to Russia and widen sanctions over Ukraine conflict

standfirst:
Separatist leader says they will guarantee safety of crash site observers in return for a Kiev-backed truce, amid accusations rebels are tampering with evidence and removing bodies from the site

  • Aids conference begins with 'gaping hole in our hearts'
  • Putin given 'one last chance' as world fury mounts
  • Rebels fuel chaos as rotting corpses pile up on the roadside
  • Hard line will push Russia into an ever-tighter corner
  • Russia is not yet ready to abandon rebel groups
  • Editorial: It's time brutish Putin was held to account
headline: MH17: Rebels promise safe access to site in return for truce - as it happened

standfirst: Photographs from the Guardian Eyewitness series
headline: Eyewitness: Hrabove, Ukraine

standfirst: Australian prime minister Tony Abbott has told parliament those responsible for shooting down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 'must be brought to justice'. He said Australia would seek a binding resolution through the UN security council for a full investigation. The bodies of the Australians killed would be repatriated as quickly as possible, he said, adding 'the bullying of small countries by big ones ... should have no place in our world'.
headline: Tony Abbott calls for justice after Malaysia Airlines disaster – video

standfirst: Russian president says sanctions announced on Wednesday will strain bilateral relations and hurt Russian and US businesses
headline: Vladimir Putin condemns latest US sanctions against Russia

standfirst: Melbourne conference organisers confirm names of seven delegates on board with 28 Australian victims
headline: Number of Aids researchers on flight MH17 'smaller than reported'

standfirst: Australia's foreign minister Julie Bishop has urged pro-Russia separatists in eastern Ukraine to co-operate with an investigation into the explosion of flight MH17, asking for Australian consulate staff to be given access to the crash site. At least 27 Australian citizens are believed to have been on board the flight
headline: MH17: Australian foreign minister Julie Bishop urges Ukraine rebels to co-operate with investigation - video

standfirst: Former US secretary of state Hillary Clinton has said if Malaysia Airways flight MH17 was shot down by a surface-to-air missile as believed by US intelligence agencies, then "the equipment had to have come from Russia". Should Russia's assistance be proven, she called for Europe to step up sanctions against Russia and to "put Putin on notice that he has gone too far and we are not going to stand idly by".
headline: Hillary Clinton says Russian-backed rebels likely shot down plane – video

standfirst: As UN considers strongly worded proposal, Ukraine rebel leader says investigators can access site if Kiev agrees a ceasefire
headline: MH17: UN draft resolution demands 'guilty should be held to account'

standfirst: Our reporter at scene of downed Malaysian airliner sees debris and body parts across huge area near Russia-Ukraine border
headline: MH17 crash site: impact threw us to the ground, say shocked witnesses

standfirst:
• Kerry 'We have enormous input about this that points fingers'
• US secretary of state calls on Russia to help full investigation
headline: MH17: Kerry says all evidence points to separatists and urges Russia to 'step up'

standfirst:
• Secretary of state speaks to Russian foreign minister
• Russia calls for 'unbiased, open, international investigation'

• Pro-Russia rebels deny access to crash site
• Russian media blame Ukraine government
• Masha Alekhina: press is covering up Putin's complicity
headline: MH17: Kerry expresses US concern over reports bodies and debris moved

standfirst: Russian president Vladimir Putin warns on Wednesday that US sanctions will take relations with Russia to a 'dead end' and damage US business interests in his country. The latest US sanctions target two major energy firms, a pair of powerful financial institutions, eight weapons firms and four individuals. They are intended to end the insurgency in eastern Ukraine that is widely believed to be backed by the Kremlin
headline: Vladimir Putin condemns US sanctions against Russia – video

standfirst: Three mortars fired into Israel during five-hour 'humanitarian pause' in hostilities brokered by UN
headline: Mortars fired from Gaza during ceasefire between Israel and Hamas

standfirst: All flights now barred from eastern Ukraine, where airliner was downed while reportedly flying 1,000ft above restricted airspace
headline: Downed Malaysia Airlines plane: how did it go wrong for flight MH17?

standfirst:
As experts from the UK and Malaysia arrive in Kiev to assist a Ukrainian-led investigation into how flight MH17 was brought down, the world pays its respects to the dead

MH17: Ukraine accuses rebels of destroying evidence - live updates
headline: Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 crash – in pictures

standfirst: Vice president of Malaysia Airlines Europe, Huib Gorter, has told the media what he knows about the number of people killed on Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which is thought to have been shot down over eastern Ukraine by separatist fighters. For more go to the live blog
headline: Malaysia Airlines VP announces nationalities of MH17 passengers – video

standfirst: Schiphol passenger reaction typified by: 'This is something that never, ever happens. It's unlikely to happen again.'
headline: Dutch travellers react calmly to loss of flight MH17

standfirst: Australian foreign minister says UN resolution is needed to ensure bodies can be repatriated and crash site examined
headline: MH17 crash: Julie Bishop urges Russia to back swift investigation

standfirst: Tony Abbott has branded the scene at the site of the MH17 disaster 'absolutely shambolic' and pushed for the repatriation of the 37 Australians killed. Abbott also said that in his most recent conversations with Vladimir Putin, the Russian president had 'said all the right things', 'but the challenge now is to hold the president to his word'
headline: Malaysia Airlines crash site 'absolutely shambolic', says Australian PM – video

standfirst: Rebel groups in eastern Ukraine have allegedly been shooting at planes and helicopters with Buk missiles over past week
headline: Malaysia Airlines plane may have been shot down by Buk missile

standfirst: Experts fear that evidence of how the Malaysia Airlines MH17 plane was brought down could be lost for ever as evidence disappears from the crash site
headline: MH17 crash site chaos - in pictures

standfirst: Move means special meeting of EU foreign ministers is unlikely to press ahead with generalised economic sanctions
headline: MH17 black box handover set to delay escalation of sanctions against Russia

standfirst: First OSCE investigators to the scene retreat after hour-long standoff with armed separatists who fired warning shots
headline: MH17: rebels block access to part of site of crash as evidence against them grows

standfirst:
• This blog has now ended: Read our latest story here
  • Obama confirms surface-to-air missile was used
  • Airlines change flight paths to avoid Ukraine
  • Putin calls for opposing sides in Ukraine to lay down arms
  • US president blames disaster on pro-Russia rebels
  • Ukrainian, Russian and rebel leaders deny involvement
  • UN demands full inquiry
  • MH17 crash in pictures
headline: Pro-Russia rebels accused of cover-up over MH17 atrocity - live updates

standfirst: World leaders, including David Cameron, Barack Obama and Angela Merkel, condemn the shooting down of Malaysia Airline flight MH17, which crashed in Ukraine on Thursday killing all 283 passengers and 15 crew. Malaysian prime minister, Najib Razak, calls for those responsible to be brought to justice. Australian prime minister, Tony Abbott, says Russia's claim that Ukraine should bear responsibility for the crash is 'deeply, deeply unsatisfactory'
headline: Malaysia Airlines crash: world leaders condemn attack - video

standfirst: Kiev says it has proof that missile launchers with Russian crews crossed into Ukraine as fears mount that rebels are destroying evidence and removing bodies from the crash site
headline: MH17:  Ukraine claims 'compelling evidence' of Russian involvement - live updates

standfirst: Measures target some of the country's largest energy corporations and banks, and a handful of senior Russian officials
headline: US significantly escalates sanctions against Russia over Ukraine

standfirst: Firefighters and journalists discuss Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which was shot down in eastern Ukraine on Thursday by a ground-to-air missile, killing 283 passengers and 15 crew. Nine Britons are among the dead. Ukrainian rebels are being blamed for shooting down the plane with a Russian-made missile
headline: Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 shot down in Ukraine – video report

standfirst: Russian president Vladimir Putin reacts on Thursday to the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in Ukraine. Putin says Russia asks his advisers to observe a minute of silence for the victims. Ukraine has accused pro-Moscow militants, aided by Russia, of firing a long-range, Soviet-era SA-11 ground-to-air missile. But Putin levels the blame against Ukraine
headline: Ukraine responsible for Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 disaster, says Vladimir Putin – video

standfirst: Thousands of miles apart, family and friends united in mourning for those killed when missile downed flight MH17 in east Ukraine
headline: Malaysia Airlines crash: across globe, prayers said as grief turns to despair

standfirst:
Following new developments and global reaction overnight, here is a roundup of what we know about Thursday's crash in the Ukraine

Follow today's live blog on the MH17 crash
headline: Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash: what we know so far

standfirst: British Airways, Qantas and Cathay Pacific among those who have taken detours around area where MH17 was brought down
headline: Many airlines have avoided Ukrainian airspace for months

standfirst: In a televised address, Ukrainian president, Petro Poroshenko, appeals to the global community to treat the missile attack on MH17 as more than just a local problem, calling the attack an act of terrorism and a wake-up call for the whole world. Investigations are continuing as suspicions mount that pro-Russian separatists shot down the plane
headline: Russian aggression is a threat to global security, Ukraine president says after MH17 crash - video

standfirst:
• Pro-Russia rebels suspected of downing airliner
• Ukrainian president condemns 'terrorist act'
• World leaders react with shock and revulsion

• Follow the latest developments on our live blog
headline: Missile destroys Malaysia Airlines plane over Ukraine, killing 298 people

standfirst: Airline says it had believed flight path over increasingly volatile region was safe, but will now take alternative route
headline: Malaysia Airlines changes route over eastern Ukraine after MH17 shot down

standfirst: After the loss of so many innocent lives, the international community has to find a way to prevent the stand-off from reaching an even more dangerous level, says Dmitri Trenin
headline: 'Tragedy of flight MH17 must mark final point in Ukraine conflict'

standfirst: These are some of the faces of passengers who on board MH17 when it was apparently shot down over Ukraine
headline: Australians who died on flight MH17 – in pictures

standfirst: Najib Razak calls for justice, saying air disaster ‘a tragic day, in what has already been a tragic year, for Malaysia’
headline: MH17 crash: investigators must have full access to site, says Malaysian PM

standfirst: US President Barack Obama discusses on Friday the shooting down a Malaysian passenger plane in east Ukraine on Thursday. Obama emphasised the need for cooperation in the investigation into what happened and vowed to get to the truth of the matter. A team of nearly 30 OSCE observers attempted for second time to gain access to the crash site on Saturday after meeting resistance from armed rebels on Friday
headline: Malaysia Airlines plane crash: 'an outrage of unspeakable proportions', says Obama - video

standfirst:
A friend pays tribute to the Dutch citizen killed in airliner shot down over Ukraine, who was an enthusiastic writer and political activist and 'most of all loved by many'

Follow today's developments following the MH17 crash in Ukraine
headline: Pim de Kuijer, my friend and Aids campaigner, killed in MH17 crash

standfirst:
• Separatists receiving anti-aircraft training 'from Russia'
• President confirms one US citizen among dead
headline: Obama says destruction of MH17 is a 'wake-up call' for Europe

standfirst: Malaysia expresses concerns that the crash site of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 has not been properly secured. The country's transport minister calls on all parties to respect the integrity of the crash site. Pressure is mounting on Russia and Ukraine, who blame each other for the incident, as members of the international community worst affected by the crash call for answers
headline: Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 crash site integrity may be compromised, says Malaysia - video

standfirst: The world is demanding answers from Russia after a Malaysia Airlines jet's destruction over Donetsk, Ukraine, near the Russian border. The area has seen violent clashes between Ukrainian and pro-Russia separatists since the annexation of Crimea in February
headline: Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 crash – in pictures
